values: Equivalent CO2 used to represent radiative forcing of GHG except water vapor. Two time period aerosol concentration distributions specified (1985 and 2050). Also given is the total globally averaged aerosol optical depth. To find any given year, the ratio of the global averages and weighting in time fo the map time periods was performed. To convert the interpolated aerosol value into a forcing, the surface albedos were modified using the Haywood et al. method. Volcanoes were represented as a change in the solar constant. Solar changes also changed the solar constant.
Y: Prescribed concentrations, distributions or time series data
N/A: Not applicable - forcing agent is not included
N/A: Not applicable - forcing agent is not included
C: Fixed prescribed climatology of concentrations with no year-to-year variability

aerosol effects put into model via changes in surface albedo. Haywood et al.
Damp mean wind in spectral space
Fels-Schwartzkopf shortwave radiation. Manabe-Strickler longwave radiation.  Equivalent CO2 is used in historical and future scenarios.
Manabe Moist Convective Adjustment. Single pass per time step.
none. Precipitation is simulated whenever a grid box relative humidity is greatly than 100%.
Cloud fills grid box whenever relative humidity is 100%.
Scheme based on roughness of subgrid orography. Tuned to give good zonally averaged sea level pressure simulation.
Solar constant. Volcanoes included via solar constant changes.
SW radiation: Shortwave solar spectral irradiance.
Volcanoes are included via solat constant changes.
sigma: allows vertical coordinate to follow model terrain

Atmosphere dynamical core is spectral. R30 truncation. Manabe Moist Convective adjustment (MVA) is used. Diffusive boundary layer. Fels-Schwartzkopf shortwave radiation. Manabe-Strickler longwave radiation.
Does the atmosphere have a high-top? High-Top atmospheres have a fully resolved stratosphere with a model top above the stratopause.
Timestep for the longwave radiative transfer in seconds.
If the orography type is modified describe the adaptation.
Describe any time varying orographic change

General overview description of tuning: explain and motivate the main targets and metrics retained. &Document the relative weight given to climate performance metrics versus process oriented metrics, &and on the possible conflicts with parameterization level tuning. In particular describe any struggle &with a parameter value that required pushing it to its limits to solve a particular model deficiency.
Good overall simulation of present day general circulation.
List observed trend metrics used in tuning model/component
runoff is routed to ocean instantaneously using a realistic (present day river network.
Snowfall is added to snowdepth. If surface temperature tries to rise above 0C, snow is melted and temprature is set to 0C. Snow has no temperature.
Other: snow cover whole grid box
Zero heat capacity is assumed for land. Surface fluxes are balance by solving for surface temperature.
Simple. Runoff uses the river network to connect land grid box to ocean.
same as atmosphere grid 96 east-west by 80 north-south

Manabe bucket is used. Land has zero heat capacity. Non-snow or ice covered surface albedoes are specified. These albedoes are modified using a function of snowdepth and surface temperature. The surface temperature is a balance of the heat fluxes at the land surface. The bucket is 15cm deep.
Non-snow or ice covered surface albedoes are specified. These albedoes are modified using a function of snowdepth and surface temperature. Runoff is predicted when the bucket overflows.
Describe the treatment of land surface coupling with the Atmosphere model component, which may be different for different quantities (e.g. dust: semi-implicit, water vapour: explicit)
Describe the general tiling procedure used in the land surface (if any). Include treatment of physiography, land/sea, (dynamic) vegetation coverage and orography/roughness
Describe if/how carbon is conserved globally and to what level (e.g. within X [units]/year)
General description of time stepping method and associated time step(s)

General overview description of tuning (if any): explain and motivate the main targets and metrics retained. &Document the relative weight given to climate performance metrics versus process oriented metrics, &and on the possible conflicts with parameterization level tuning. In particular describe any struggle &with a parameter value that required pushing it to its limits to solve a particular model deficiency.

Ice sheets are prescribed and remain unchanged in all runs. There are no ice shelves. If surface temperature rises aboe 0C over an ice sheet and there is no snow to melt, the surface temperature is set to 0C and the heat is stored for offline analysis. The ice sheet is unchanged; no water goes into the ocean.
If the water equivalent snowdepth at a grid location exceeds 20cm, excess is routed to ocean as a frozen water flux

Land ice grid locations are set before model begin integration and held fixed with no changes. Basically Greenland and Antarctica are flagged as land ice locations. Snow can fall on these points. Snow depth changes results from snowfall and surface melt. If the surface temperature tried to rise above 0C, the surface temperature is reset to 0C and the heat is archived for analysis.
Leap-frog + Periodic Euler: Leap-frog scheme with Periodic Euler
Leap-frog + Periodic Euler: Leap-frog scheme with Periodic Euler
Leapfrog with Euler backward step every 17 time steps to filter noise/control time step splitting.
None: No diurnal cycle in ocean

no-slip sides (as per the B-grid), constant viscosity laplacian horizontal friction, isopyncal tracer diffusion (Cox MD (1987) Isopycnal diffusion in a Z-coordinate ocean model.Ocean Model 74: 1–5), does not use Gent-McWilliams eddy induced velocity.
None: No transient eddies in ocean
centered finite difference, 40m deep top grid box simulates PBL, virtual salt flux top boundary condition.
Bryan-Lewis (.3 at surface to 1 at bottom (cgs units))
rigid lid upper boundary, drag lower boundary
fluxes computed in atmosphere and passed to ocean/sea ice. Fluxes computed in sea ice passed to ocean. Ocean gives SST to sea ice code and atmosphere.
Heat and water flux adjustments are applied each time step. The adjustments are a function of I and j and month. They repeat exactly year to year and in all experiments.

Manabe bucket on land points. When bucket overflows, water is routed to ocean using present day river network. Rain at ocean grid location plus river flow passed to ocean. For large rivers, water spread over top 4 grid boxes in ocean.
Regular lat-long "B" grid with 18 vertical levels. The model uses Fourier filtering to control grid noise near the poles.
Careful attention paid to overflows, important narrow channels, ridges and etc. 2 grid point basins on UV grid were eliminated. Shallow points were deepened to 4 vertical grid levels.
Isolated inland seas on grid but not in reality are mixed using a cross land mixing code where boxes at the same grid level are mixed east-west near the location of the observed opening.
River outflow is mixed over the top 4 grid boxes at river mouths.
rigid lid, virtual salt flux, Bryan-Cox, isopycnal mixing

The component is a coupled version of MOM1 ocean model. See MOM1 documentation for complete details. Pacanowski R, Dixon K, Rosati A (1991) The GFDL ModularOcean Model users guide version 1, GFDL Ocean Group TechRep 2, pp. 44 [Available from NOAA/Geophysical Fluid Dynamics Laboratory, Princeton University, Rt. 1, Princeton, NJ 08542.
Used ocean only to tune model. Flux adjustments used in coupled model. Model tuned to yield good overall simulation.
Model conserves heat and water and salt. Online diagnostics perform checks several times per model year.
Ice moves with ocean currents only, no wind forcing. If ice greater than 4m thick, divergence only allowed.
Other: transport via ocean currents only
Other: Ice moves with ocean currents only, no wind forcing. If ice greater than 4m thick, divergence only allowed.
Ice has no temperature. Ocean must be at -2C. Heat coinduction through the ice is a square root function. Ice can melt from above or below, but all melt is applied to bottom of ice.
Other: all melt occurs at bottom of ice.
assumed to be same temperature as ocean.
Snow fals on the ice and is added to ice thickness. Rain is added directly to ocean under ice.
Ice can sublimate if surface relative humidity less than 100%.
Sea ice is freshwater when melted. Ice has no salinity.
Other: cocnetration = 1 or 0, no thickness categories
Surface albedo a square root function of thickness. If surface temperature goes above freezing, albedo is reduced. Thee is no snow on sea ice in this model.
Parameterized: Sea ice albedo is parameterized.
Sea ice on the ocean grid.
Ocean grid: Sea ice is horizontally discretised on the ocean grid.
Zero-layer: Simulation has no internal ice thermodynamics.

Ice has no temperature. Ice covers entire grid box, no leads, concentration = 1 or 0. Ice moves with ocean currents only, no wind forcing. Snow that falls on sea ice is added to thickness. Ice can melt from top or bottom.
Constant: Constant value of seawater freezing point is used.
Simple sea ice model from 1970's and 80's.
ice movement with wind, leads, etc.
heat and water fluxes were adjusted in an attempt to maintain sea ice edge.

Flux adjustments are used. The fluxes are not corrected in any way. The flux adjustments are intended to keep SST and SSS realistic.  The flux adjustments are computed in 2 steps. First and atmosphere-only model is run to equilibrium (about 20 years). The surface fluxes are archived (monthly averages). Step 2 the fluxes from step 1 are input to an ocean only model which is also run to equilibrium (about 4000 model years). The SST and SSS in the ocean model are restored towards observations using a Haney type restoring. The time averages of the restoring terms at equilibrium are the flux adjustments used in the AOGCM.
atmosphere-land coupled to ocean-sea ice model. The coupler conserves heat and water written by Stouffer in 1985.
R30 spectral atmosphere coupled to MOM1 ocean using simple Manabe land model and simple Bryan sea ice model.
atmosphere - ocean components conserve as does the coupler.

atmosphere - ocean components conserve as does the coupler. The coupler does no interpolations. Two ocean-sea ice grid boxes (east-west) lie underneath 1 atmosphere-land grid box - exactly. Fluxes into ocean-sea ice are split into two and passed to each ocean box. SST is averaged and passed up to atmosphere box.
Two ocean grid boxes underly each atmosphere grid box. Land-sea boundary set by atmosphere grid. Atmosphere flux from each grid atm grid box is passed to both ocean-sea ice boxes underlying it.

Two ocean grid boxes underly each atmosphere grid box. Land-sea boundary set by atmosphere grid. Atmosphere flux from each grid atm grid box is passed to both ocean-sea ice boxes underlying it. Sea ice thickness is averaged and passed up to atmosphere box.
Freezing is set to -2C. If ocean temperature drops below -2C, sea ice is formed. No sensible heat storage in sea ice. They are on same grid exactly. No conservation issue.
No heat is exchanged between the land and ocean. Just water which has no temperature.
Two ocean grid boxes underly each atmosphere grid box. Land-sea boundary set by atmosphere grid. Atmosphere flux from each  atmosphere grid box is passed to both ocean-sea ice boxes underlying it.
Two ocean grid boxes underly each atmosphere grid box. Land-sea boundary set by atmosphere grid. Atmosphere flux from each grid atm grid box is passed to both ocean-sea ice boxes underlying it.
Manabe bucket model is used (Manabe 1969). Runoff is routed to ocean via a realistic river network. Land and atmosphere use same grid exactly.
All frozen water is added to sea ice thickness. See above.
Freezing/melt is taken from/added to SSS. See above.
Snow depth is not allowed to exceed 20 cm water equivalent. Any snow depth greater than 20 cm is sent to ocean as a frozen water flux using the river network.
Snowfall is added to snow depth. If surface temperature exceeds 0C, snow melts. No snow on sea ice.

Two ocean grid boxes underly each atmosphere grid box. Land-sea boundary set by atmosphere grid. Atmosphere flux from each grid atm grid box is passed to both ocean-sea ice boxes underlying it.  Virtual salt flux formulation.
Two ocean grid boxes underly each atmosphere grid box. Land-sea boundary set by atmosphere grid. Atmosphere flux from each grid atm grid box is passed to both ocean-sea ice boxes underlying it.
